introduction.content: Multiprincipal element alloys (MPEAs), also known as high entropy alloys, have garnered attention in recent years due to their excellent mechanical and physical properties stemming from their unique chemical complexity. Unlike conventional alloys, MPEAs are composed of multiple elements in high concentration. MPEAs comprising 3d transition metals have been widely explored due to their extraordinary strength and ductility at room [1] , [2] , [3] and cryogenic temperatures [4] owing to their low stacking fault energies and consequent additional deformation mechanisms [5] . In the context of additive manufacturing (AM), MPEAs offer a compelling avenue for the fabrication of high-performance components. Processing MPEAs via AM has led to improvements in properties such as strength [6] , [7] and corrosion resistance [8] compared to parts fabricated by conventional manufacturing methods such as casting. However, the AM processing of MPEAs presents challenges, just like in conventional alloys, particularly in material systems that solidify along preferred crystal orientations [9] . The high thermal gradients, rapid cooling rates, and partial remelting of previous layers can lead to the growth of columnar grains, resulting in highly textured microstructures. Previous investigations have highlighted the potential of composition as a parameter to alter microstructures in AM [10] , [11] . However, a deeper understanding of the composition-driven process-structure-property relationships in MPEAs will enable the strategic use of targeted compositions at specified locations to enhance the strength and performance of printed components [12] . Successful examples of alloy design strategies for grain refinement in AM include combining pre-existing alloys such as titanium alloys, nickel-based superalloys, and stainless steels to create new materials [13] , [14] , decorating the powder feedstock with nucleant particles [15] , and adding alloying elements to increase constitutional supercooling ahead of the solidification front [16] . In MPEAs, one effective method for changing the microstructure is to introduce a secondary phase by varying the composition of the alloy, such as adding aluminum, titanium, and niobium to MPEAs with 3d transition metals [17] , [18] , [19] , [20] , [21] , [22] . Secondary phases such as body-centered cubic (bcc), Huesler-like ordered L2 1 phase, and Laves phase emerge to pin grain boundaries and break down epitaxial grain growth [23] . However, these additional elements may lead to the formation of brittle intermetallics, which can result in significant cracking during solidification as they cannot accommodate the high residual stresses in AM. In addition, the underlying mechanism by which phase transformation leads to grain refinement remains elusive due to challenges with measuring and interpreting the spatiotemporal evolution of microstructures and defects during and after solidification has finished [24] , [25] . The current study aims to illuminate a new grain refinement mechanism in MPEAs by combining thermodynamic modeling, operando X-ray diffraction (XRD) studies, and multiscale microstructural evaluation to develop a comprehensive understanding of the intricate microstructural changes occurring during the AM process. We demonstrate an alloy design concept and adaptation for AM using a Fe 80-x Mn x Co 10 Cr 10 (at. %, x = 40, 45, and 50) MPEAs. These samples will henceforth be referred to by their Mn content, namely, Mn40, Mn45, and Mn50. In conventionally processed FeMnCoCr, decreasing the Mn content has shown a combination of exceptional strength and ductility due to the lowered stacking fault energy difference between the stable face-centered cubic (fcc) phase and deformation-induced hexagonal close-packed (hcp) phase [1] . Instead, we increase the Mn content to destabilize the primary fcc phase during solidification to enable microstructure control in a direct energy deposition (DED) system where the microstructure generally tends to be more columnar due to its lower scanning speeds compared to powder-bed fusion (PBF) [10] . FeMnCoCr enables us to shed light on the complex relationship of composition, phase stability, process, microstructure, and properties to achieve a crack-free, refined microstructure in AM.

1.33: The metastability-engineering strategy should guide design in the near-infinite compositional space of high-entropy alloys.

sentences.sentence: In MPEAs, one effective method for changing the microstructure is to introduce a secondary phase by varying the composition of the alloy, such as adding aluminum, titanium, and niobium to MPEAs with 3d transition metals [17], [18], [19], [20], [21], [22].

17.1: Hot tearing is a major hindrance for alloy design in additive manufacturing.
17.2: Previous works have tried to reduce the solidification range to prevent hot tearing.
17.3: Previous works have tried to introduce grain refinement to prevent hot tearing.
17.4: The current work presents a new approach using segregation engineering to alter residual stress states at interdendritic and grain boundary regions.
17.5: The current work aims to prevent hot tearing by altering residual stress states through segregation engineering.
17.6: In situ Al alloying is introduced in a high-entropy alloy CoCrFeNi that is susceptible to hot-cracking.
17.7: Within a certain range of compositions including Al0.5CoCrFeNi, the hot crack density is drastically decreased.
17.8: During solidification of the alloy composition, Al is ejected from the primary dendritic FCC phase.
17.9: Al segregates into the interdendritic regions during solidification of the alloy composition.
17.10: Spinodal decomposition occurs in Al-enriched regions to form the ordered B2 NiAl phase.
17.11: Spinodal decomposition occurs in Al-enriched regions to form the disordered body-centred cubic (BCC) Cr phase.
17.12: The B2/BCC phases have higher molar volume and lower homologous temperatures than other phases.
17.13: The inherent residual strain is transformed from a maximum 0.006 tensile strain in CoCrFeNi to a compressive strain of ~0.001 in Al0.5CoCrFeNi.
17.14: The grain boundary segregation engineering method could provide a new pathway to counteract the hot tearing problem in additive manufacturing.
17.15: Available thermodynamic and kinetic database information can be used in applying the grain boundary segregation engineering method.

18.1: Ordered L21 Huesler phases exhibit interesting magnetic properties.
18.2: Ordered L21 Huesler phases are known to substantially enhance creep resistance in multi-phase alloys.
18.3: Experimental evidence of a Huesler-like ordered L21 phase in a multicomponent High Entropy Alloy (HEA) is presented.
18.4: The titanium induced stabilization of the Huesler-like ordered L21 phase is rationalized based on first principles calculations.
18.5: The composition of High Entropy Alloys (HEAs) can be tuned to obtain the desired microstructure.
18.6: The composition of High Entropy Alloys (HEAs) can potentially be tailored to obtain desired properties.

20.1: An interstitial solute strengthened high entropy alloy (iHEA), Fe49.5Mn30Co10Cr10C0.5 (at.%), was successfully manufactured additively.
20.2: The manufacturing method used for iHEA was selective laser melting.
20.3: The as-built iHEA exhibits a hierarchically heterogeneous microstructure.
20.4: The microstructure of iHEA spans several orders of magnitude in length scales.
20.5: The hierarchically heterogeneous microstructure of as-built iHEA leads to an enhanced strength–ductility combination.
20.6: The strength–ductility combination of the as-built iHEA is enhanced compared to high entropy alloys fabricated by conventional processing routes.
20.7: The high yield strength of as-built iHEA mainly stems from dislocation strengthening.
20.8: The high yield strength of as-built iHEA is also supported by friction stress.
20.9: Grain boundary strengthening contributes to the high yield strength of the as-built iHEA.
20.10: The steady work-hardening behavior at high stress levels in as-built iHEA is maintained by the joint activation of multiple deformation mechanisms.
20.11: The deformation mechanisms involved in maintaining work-hardening behavior include dislocation slip.
20.12: Deformation twinning is one of the mechanisms involved in maintaining work-hardening behavior.
20.13: Phase transformation contributes as a mechanism to maintain work-hardening behavior.
20.14: The maintenance of steady work-hardening behavior at high stress levels leads to high ductility in as-built iHEA.

21.1: Additive manufacturing produces net-shaped components layer by layer.
21.2: Additive manufacturing is used for engineering applications.
21.3: The additive manufacture of metal alloys by laser powder bed fusion (L-PBF) involves large temperature gradients.
21.4: The additive manufacture of metal alloys by laser powder bed fusion (L-PBF) involves rapid cooling.
21.5: Large temperature gradients and rapid cooling enable microstructural refinement at the nanoscale.
21.6: Microstructural refinement at the nanoscale achieves high strength in metal alloys.
21.7: High-strength nanostructured alloys produced by laser additive manufacturing often have limited ductility.
21.8: L-PBF is used to print dual-phase nanolamellar high-entropy alloys (HEAs) of AlCoCrFeNi₂.₁.
21.9: The nanolamellar high-entropy alloys (HEAs) of AlCoCrFeNi₂.₁ exhibit a high yield strength of about 1.3 gigapascals.
21.10: The nanolamellar high-entropy alloys (HEAs) of AlCoCrFeNi₂.₁ exhibit a large uniform elongation of about 14 per cent.
21.11: The combination of high yield strength and large uniform elongation in AlCoCrFeNi₂.₁ surpasses those of other state-of-the-art additively manufactured metal alloys.
21.12: High yield strength stems from the strong strengthening effects of dual-phase structures.
21.13: Dual-phase structures consist of alternating face-centred cubic and body-centred cubic nanolamellae.
21.14: Body-centred cubic nanolamellae exhibit higher strengths than face-centred cubic nanolamellae.
21.15: Body-centred cubic nanolamellae exhibit higher hardening rates than face-centred cubic nanolamellae.
21.16: Large tensile ductility arises owing to the high work-hardening capability of as-printed hierarchical microstructures.
21.17: Hierarchical microstructures are in the form of dual-phase nanolamellae embedded in microscale eutectic colonies.
21.18: Microscale eutectic colonies have nearly random orientations.
21.19: Nearly random orientations promote isotropic mechanical properties.
21.20: Mechanistic insights into the deformation behaviour of additively manufactured HEAs have broad implications for developing nanostructured alloys.
21.21: Mechanistic insights into the deformation behaviour are relevant for developing hierarchical structures.
21.22: Mechanistic insights into the deformation behaviour are relevant for developing dual-phase structures.
21.23: Mechanistic insights into the deformation behaviour are relevant for developing multi-phase structures.
21.24: Mechanistic insights into the deformation behaviour are relevant for developing alloys with exceptional mechanical properties.

22.1: Bulk CoCrFeNiNbx high entropy alloys were fabricated successfully.
22.2: The fabrication method used was direct laser deposition.
22.3: The microstructures of the as-deposited CoCrFeNiNbx high entropy alloys were investigated.
22.4: The mechanical properties of the as-deposited CoCrFeNiNbx high entropy alloys were investigated.
22.5: The work-hardening behavior of the as-deposited CoCrFeNiNbx high entropy alloys was investigated.
22.6: Uniform microstructures were characterized in longitudinal sections of the as-deposited CoCrFeNiNbx high entropy alloys.
22.7: Fully compact microstructures were characterized in longitudinal sections of the as-deposited CoCrFeNiNbx high entropy alloys.
22.8: Uniform microstructures were characterized in transverse sections of the as-deposited CoCrFeNiNbx high entropy alloys.
22.9: Fully compact microstructures were characterized in transverse sections of the as-deposited CoCrFeNiNbx high entropy alloys.
22.10: No apparent pores were observed in any samples of the as-deposited CoCrFeNiNbx high entropy alloys.
22.11: No microcracks were observed in any samples of the as-deposited CoCrFeNiNbx high entropy alloys.
22.12: A transition from columnar to equiaxed grain structures was noted in the as-deposited CoCrFeNiNbx high entropy alloys.
22.13: The transition from columnar to equiaxed grain structures was associated with increasing Nb content.
22.14: Room temperature tensile tests demonstrated an excellent combination of strength and ductility in the as-deposited CoCrFeNiNbx high entropy alloys.
22.15: The combination of strength and ductility in the as-deposited CoCrFeNiNbx high entropy alloys was superior compared to as-cast counterparts.
22.16: The CoCrFeNiNbx high entropy alloys exhibited better printability than other high entropy alloys processed via direct laser deposition.
22.17: The CoCrFeNiNbx high entropy alloys exhibited superior mechanical properties than other high entropy alloys processed via direct laser deposition.

viewpoints: Introducing a secondary phase is an effective method for changing the microstructure in multiprincipal element alloys.
Varying the composition of multiprincipal element alloys can introduce a secondary phase.
Adding aluminum, titanium, and niobium to multiprincipal element alloys with 3d transition metals can introduce a secondary phase.

sentences.sentence: Secondary phases such as body-centered cubic (bcc), Huesler-like ordered L2 1 phase, and Laves phase emerge to pin grain boundaries and break down epitaxial grain growth [23].

23.1: High Entropy Alloys are inherently complex.
23.2: High Entropy Alloys span a vast composition space.
23.3: The inherent complexity and vast composition space of High Entropy Alloys make their research challenging.
23.4: The inherent complexity and vast composition space of High Entropy Alloys make their discovery challenging.
23.5: Developing quantitative predictions of phase selection for High Entropy Alloys requires a large quantity of experimental data.
23.6: The experimental data required for phase selection predictions for High Entropy Alloys must be consistently determined.
23.7: Combinatorial methods are used to fabricate and characterize 2478 quinary alloys.
23.8: The 2478 quinary alloys fabricated and characterized are based on Al and transition metals.
23.9: Phase selection for considered alloys can be predicted by combining the content of FCC elements and BCC elements.
23.10: Phase selection for considered alloys can be predicted by combining the constituents' atomic size difference.
23.11: High Entropy Alloys with increasing atomic size difference prefer BCC structure over FCC.
23.12: Data mining reveals the preference of High Entropy Alloys with increasing atomic size difference for BCC structure over FCC.
23.13: The preference for BCC structure over FCC in High Entropy Alloys with increasing atomic size difference is typically overshadowed by other selection motifs.
23.14: Other selection motifs dominate during close-to-equilibrium processing of High Entropy Alloys.
23.15: The preference for BCC structure in High Entropy Alloys with a large atomic size difference is not suggested by the Hume-Rothery rules.
23.16: The preference for BCC structure originates from its ability to accommodate a large atomic size difference with lower strain energy penalty.
23.17: The ability to accommodate a large atomic size difference with lower strain energy penalty can be practically realized only in High Entropy Alloys.

viewpoints: Body-centered cubic phase is a secondary phase that can emerge in multiprincipal element alloys.
Huesler-like ordered L2 1 phase is a secondary phase that can emerge in multiprincipal element alloys.
Laves phase is a secondary phase that can emerge in multiprincipal element alloys.
Secondary phases can pin grain boundaries.
Secondary phases can break down epitaxial grain growth.

sentences.sentence: However, these additional elements may lead to the formation of brittle intermetallics, which can result in significant cracking during solidification as they cannot accommodate the high residual stresses in AM.
viewpoints: Additional elements in multiprincipal element alloys may lead to the formation of brittle intermetallics.
Brittle intermetallics can result in significant cracking during solidification.
Brittle intermetallics cannot accommodate high residual stresses in additive manufacturing.

sentences.sentence: In addition, the underlying mechanism by which phase transformation leads to grain refinement remains elusive due to challenges with measuring and interpreting the spatiotemporal evolution of microstructures and defects during and after solidification has finished [24], [25].
viewpoints: The mechanism by which phase transformation leads to grain refinement is not well understood.
Challenges exist in measuring and interpreting the spatiotemporal evolution of microstructures and defects.
Challenges in understanding grain refinement occur during and after solidification.

sentences.sentence: The current study aims to illuminate a new grain refinement mechanism in MPEAs by combining thermodynamic modeling, operando X-ray diffraction (XRD) studies, and multiscale microstructural evaluation to develop a comprehensive understanding of the intricate microstructural changes occurring during the AM process.
viewpoints: The study aims to illuminate a new grain refinement mechanism in multiprincipal element alloys.
The study combines thermodynamic modeling, operando X-ray diffraction studies, and multiscale microstructural evaluation.
The study aims to develop a comprehensive understanding of microstructural changes during the additive manufacturing process.

sentences.sentence: We demonstrate an alloy design concept and adaptation for AM using a Fe 80-x Mn x Co 10 Cr 10 (at. %, x = 40, 45, and 50) MPEAs.
viewpoints: The study demonstrates an alloy design concept for additive manufacturing.
The study demonstrates adaptation for additive manufacturing using Fe 80-x Mn x Co 10 Cr 10 multiprincipal element alloys with x = 40, 45, and 50.

sentences.sentence: These samples will henceforth be referred to by their Mn content, namely, Mn40, Mn45, and Mn50.
viewpoints: The samples will be referred to by their Mn content: Mn40, Mn45, and Mn50.

sentences.sentence: In conventionally processed FeMnCoCr, decreasing the Mn content has shown a combination of exceptional strength and ductility due to the lowered stacking fault energy difference between the stable face-centered cubic (fcc) phase and deformation-induced hexagonal close-packed (hcp) phase [1].

1.1: Metals have been mankind's most essential materials for thousands of years.
1.2: The use of metals is affected by ecological concerns.
1.3: The use of metals is affected by economical concerns.
1.4: Alloys with higher strength and ductility could alleviate ecological concerns by reducing weight.
1.5: Alloys with higher strength and ductility could alleviate ecological concerns by improving energy efficiency.
1.6: Alloys with higher strength and ductility could alleviate economical concerns by reducing weight.
1.7: Alloys with higher strength and ductility could alleviate economical concerns by improving energy efficiency.
1.8: Most metallurgical mechanisms for increasing strength lead to ductility loss.
1.9: The effect where increasing strength leads to ductility loss is referred to as the strength–ductility trade-off.
1.11: The metastability-engineering strategy involves designing nanostructured, bulk high-entropy alloys.
1.12: These high-entropy alloys have multiple compositionally equivalent high-entropy phases.
1.13: High-entropy alloys were originally proposed to benefit from phase stabilization.
1.14: Phase stabilization in high-entropy alloys was proposed to occur through entropy maximization.
1.15: Recent work has relaxed the strict restrictions on high-entropy alloy compositions.
1.16: The recent work demonstrates the weakness of the connection between entropy maximization and phase stabilization.
1.17: The concept of high-entropy alloys benefiting from phase stabilization through entropy maximization is overturned.
1.18: Phase stability is decreased to achieve interface hardening.
1.19: Interface hardening is due to a dual-phase microstructure.
1.20: The dual-phase microstructure results from reduced thermal stability of the high-temperature phase.
1.21: Phase stability is decreased to achieve transformation-induced hardening.
1.22: Transformation-induced hardening results from the reduced mechanical stability of the room-temperature phase.
1.23: Extensive hardening is due to decreased phase stability known from advanced steels.
1.24: Massive solid-solution strengthening occurs in high-entropy alloys.
1.25: The strategy combines extensive hardening from advanced steels with solid-solution strengthening from high-entropy alloys.
1.26: In the transformation-induced plasticity-assisted, dual-phase high-entropy alloy (TRIP-DP-HEA), interface hardening and transformation-induced hardening lead to enhanced trans-grain slip resistance.
1.27: Interface hardening and transformation-induced hardening lead to enhanced inter-grain slip resistance in the TRIP-DP-HEA.
1.28: Enhanced trans-grain and inter-grain slip resistance lead to increased strength in the TRIP-DP-HEA.
1.29: Increased strain hardening capacity is enabled by dislocation hardening of the stable phase.
1.30: Increased strain hardening capacity is enabled by transformation-induced hardening of the metastable phase.
1.31: The increased strain hardening capacity produces increased ductility.
1.32: The combined increase in strength and ductility distinguishes the TRIP-DP-HEA alloy from other recently developed structural materials.
1.33: The metastability-engineering strategy should guide design in the near-infinite compositional space of high-entropy alloys.

viewpoints: In conventionally processed FeMnCoCr, decreasing Mn content shows exceptional strength.
In conventionally processed FeMnCoCr, decreasing Mn content shows exceptional ductility.
The exceptional properties are due to a lowered stacking fault energy difference between the stable face-centered cubic phase and deformation-induced hexagonal close-packed phase.

sentences.sentence: Instead, we increase the Mn content to destabilize the primary fcc phase during solidification to enable microstructure control in a direct energy deposition (DED) system where the microstructure generally tends to be more columnar due to its lower scanning speeds compared to powder-bed fusion (PBF) [10].

10.2: The disruptive potential of additive manufacturing relies on its ability to make customized products.
10.3: Additive manufacturing enables considerable weight savings in products.
10.4: Additive manufacturing can create geometries that are difficult or impossible to produce by conventional methods.
10.5: Applications of additive manufacturing have been restricted despite its versatility.
10.6: The restriction in applications of additive manufacturing is due to the formation of columnar grains.
10.7: Columnar grains in additive manufacturing result in solidification defects.
10.8: Columnar grains in additive manufacturing lead to anisotropy in properties.
10.9: Fine equiaxed grains in additive manufacturing are achieved through optimized alloy design.
10.10: Fine equiaxed grains in additive manufacturing are achieved through optimized solidification conditions.
10.11: Alloy design and solidification conditions have been optimized in various alloy systems for additive manufacturing.
10.12: The review paper investigates the microstructure of high-entropy alloy parts.
10.13: The high-entropy alloy parts investigated are produced by selective laser melting.
10.14: The high-entropy alloy parts investigated are produced by powder-based directed energy deposition.
10.15: Solidification maps for high-entropy alloys are based on laser process parameters.
10.16: The solidification maps constructed are based on laser process parameters instead of solidification velocity and temperature gradient.
10.17: The solidification maps for high-entropy alloys are compiled from available literature.
10.18: The solidification maps are constructed for single-phase face-centered cubic high-entropy alloys.
10.19: The solidification maps are constructed for body-centered cubic high-entropy alloys.
10.20: The solidification maps are constructed for multiphase high-entropy alloys.
10.21: Solidification maps could guide the printing of high-entropy alloys.
10.22: Solidification maps could provide insight into the design of novel high-entropy alloys for additive manufacturing.

viewpoints: The study increases Mn content to destabilize the primary face-centered cubic phase during solidification.
Destabilizing the primary face-centered cubic phase enables microstructure control in a direct energy deposition system.
In a direct energy deposition system, the microstructure tends to be more columnar due to lower scanning speeds compared to powder-bed fusion.

sentences.sentence: FeMnCoCr enables us to shed light on the complex relationship of composition, phase stability, process, microstructure, and properties to achieve a crack-free, refined microstructure in AM.
viewpoints: FeMnCoCr helps to understand the complex relationship between composition, phase stability, process, microstructure, and properties.
Understanding these relationships helps achieve a crack-free, refined microstructure in additive manufacturing.
